items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels are high but falling slowly at our Longacre borehole in the Lambourn Valley. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year, and communities may continue to be affected by groundwater flooding as the catchment remains sensitive to further rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. 

The weather forecast for the next week is dry on Friday and most of Saturday, with further unsettled weather expected from Sunday, 26/05/2024. Low-lying land, gardens, roads, and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. 

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. Avoid driving or walking through floodwater as there may be concealed hazards. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week by Friday, 31/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Candovers and Old Alresford
items.message: Groundwater levels are high but falling slowly. In the last week, the level at Preston Candover has fallen by 17cm. At Old Alresford the level has fallen by 19cm. Cellar flooding is expected to be affecting a small number of properties in Preston Candover and Old Alresford. Septic tanks will be struggling to operate effectively. Today (22/05/2024), showers are forecast to affect Hampshire, with up to 40mm of rain possible. From Thursday 23/05/2024 to Monday 27/05/2024, only light showers are expected. Groundwater levels may stabilise or rise slightly in response to heavy rainfall but will begin falling again within a day. Flooding impacts are expected to continue well into June. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Wednesday 29/05/2024.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
This flood alert has been removed. 

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 

The forecast is for a band of rain tomorrow morning, and further unsettled weather for much of the week. River levels have stabilised below the flood risk threshold but are sensitive to further rainfall. 

Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Henley and Assendon area
items.message:
Groundwater levels are high but falling slowly at our Stonor Estate borehole near Henley and Assendon. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year, and communities may continue to be affected by groundwater flooding as the catchment remains sensitive to further rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. 

The weather forecast for the next week is dry on Friday and most of Saturday, with further unsettled weather expected from Sunday, 26/05/2024. Low-lying land, gardens, roads, and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. 

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. Avoid driving or walking through floodwater as there may be concealed hazards. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week by Friday, 31/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thame, Horsenden Stream and Chalgrove Brook

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high, but falling slowly on the River Thame as a result of previous heavy rainfall moving through the system. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today, 28/05/2024, especially in areas of Stadhampton near the River Thame. 

The forecast is for widespread rain throughout the day, with isolated showers tomorrow, and further unsettled weather for much of the week. River levels are expected to remain high for several days and are sensitive to further rainfall. 

We are monitoring the situation. Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated this evening, 28/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Pang from East Ilsley to Pangbourne and Sulham Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high, but falling slowly, on the River Pang following recent rainfall and high groundwater levels. Flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible today and in the days to come, especially in areas closest to the River Pang in the Tidmarsh area. 

The weather forecast for this week is dry on Friday and most of Saturday with further unsettled weather expected from Sunday, 26/05/2024. River levels are expected to remain high and will be sensitive to further rainfall. 

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated on Friday, 31/05/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: Flood water is receding from the causeways at Sutton Gault. Due to the uneven surface of the road deep puddles may be encountered. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: River Coln and its tributaries
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high on the River Coln following rainfall over recent months and high groundwater levels. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue over the coming days, especially in the Fairford area. 

The weather forecast for this week is dry on Friday and most of Saturday with further unsettled weather expected from Sunday, 26/05/2024. River levels are expected to remain high and will be sensitive to further rainfall. 

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated on Friday, 31/05/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling slowly on the River Colne, Frays, Wraysbury and Poyle Channel.

Flooding may continue to affect low lying land, particularly around Longford. No property flooding is expected.

Some further rain showers are forecast over the next few days. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10am on 28th May 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Ilsley, East Ilsley, Compton, Chilton and West Hagbourne
items.message:
Groundwater levels are high, but falling slowly at our Hodcott borehole near West Ilsley, East Ilsley and Compton. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year, and communities may continue to be affected by groundwater flooding as the catchment remains sensitive to further rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. 

The weather forecast for the next week is dry on Friday and most of Saturday, with further unsettled weather expected from Sunday, 26/05/2024. Low-lying land, gardens, roads, and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

Avoid driving or walking through floodwater as there may be concealed hazards. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week by Friday, 31/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lambourn and its tributaries from Upper Lambourn down to Newbury

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Lambourn, Great Shefford Stream, Winterbourne Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not expected. 

River levels on the Lambourn and its tributaries are high, but falling slowly due to high groundwater levels. Flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible today and in the days to come, especially in areas closest to the River Lambourn and the Winterbourne in the Bagnor area. 

The weather forecast for this week is dry on Friday and most of Saturday, with further unsettled weather expected from Sunday, 26/05/2024. River levels are expected to remain high and will be sensitive to further rainfall. 

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated on Friday, 31/05/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Bishops Sutton
items.message: Groundwater levels in Bishops Sutton are high but have fallen by 8cm in the last week. During that time, just 3mm of rain has been recorded at Bishops Sutton rain gauge. A small number of properties may still have residual water affecting their cellars. Impacts to septic tanks and flooding of roads is expected to be ongoing. Today (22/05/2024), showers are forecast to affect Hampshire, with up to 40mm of rain possible. From Thursday 23/05/2024 to Monday 27/05/2024, only light showers are expected. Groundwater levels may stabilise or rise slightly in response to heavy rainfall but will begin falling again within a day. Flooding impacts are expected to continue into early June. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Wednesday 29/05/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater levels in the villages surrounding Andover are high but continue to slowly fall. During the last week, 5mm of rain was recorded at Andover. We expect cellar flooding may still be ongoing in Hatherden and Penton Mewsey. Road flooding is occurring to the main road into Penton Grafton and the road from Biddesden to Redenham. Sewerage network and septic tank impacts are expected to be ongoing. Today (22/05/2024), showers are forecast to affect Hampshire, with up to 40mm of rain possible. From Thursday 23/05/2024 to Monday 27/05/2024, only light showers are expected. If heavy rain affects the area, groundwater levels may stabilise or slightly rise for a day, but will then quickly begin falling again. If the forecast next week is for mostly dry weather, we will remove this Flood Alert. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Wednesday 29/05/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Alton area
items.message:
Groundwater levels remain high at our Farringdon borehole near the Alton area. 

Groundwater levels remain above normal levels for this time of year but have started to decline slowly. Low lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We expect levels to continue to slowly fall over the next few weeks as we move through spring. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on 28/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Deane and Ashe in North Hampshire
items.message: Groundwater levels in Deane and Ashe are high but continue to slowly fall. During the last week, just 1mm of rain has been recorded at Overton. The level at our borehole in Oakley has fallen by 41cm during this time. Isolated properties in Deane are expected to still have a small amount of water in their cellars. Groundwater springflows are likely to be impacting land and the ability of septic tanks to operate properly. Over the next 5 days, periods of rain and showers (bringing between 5 and 35mm) are possible in Hampshire. If heavy rain affects the area, groundwater levels may stabilise for a day before falling again. Minor flooding impacts are expected to continue throughout much of this week. If relatively dry weather continues to be forecast next week, we will remove this Flood Alert. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operational. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on 28/05/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message:
Groundwater levels in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom area remain high. 

There currently remains a risk of groundwater flooding.

We expect the levels to remain high for several weeks.

We will continue to monitor the levels closely.

Be prepared to act on your flood plan if you have one.

This message will be updated by 6pm on 29th May 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Flamstead
items.message:
Groundwater levels in the Flamstead area remain high.

There remains a risk of groundwater flooding.

We expect the levels to remain high for this month.

We will continue to monitor the levels closely.

Be prepared to act on your flood plan if you have one.

This message will be updated by 6pm on 29th May 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Newmarket
items.message:
Groundwater levels are remaining low in this area but may be responsive to recent heavy rainfall . This message applies to areas of Newmarket at risk of groundwater flooding, including the High Street, and the A14 eastbound between junction 37 at Newmarket and junction 38 at Red Lodge. 

Be ready to take action to protect your property. We are monitoring the situation closely. We will update this message by 11am Wednesday 29th May 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Groundwater levels are high but falling slowly at our Chapel Wood borehole in the Leckhampstead area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year, and communities may continue to be affected by groundwater flooding as the catchment remains sensitive to further rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. 

The weather forecast for the next week is dry on Friday and most of Saturday, with further unsettled weather expected from Sunday, 26/05/2024. Low-lying land, gardens, roads, and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. 

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. Avoid driving or walking through floodwater as there may be concealed hazards. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week by Friday, 31/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Wye and The Hughenden Stream
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high but falling slowly on the Hughenden Stream due to high groundwater levels. Flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible but not expected, especially in areas closest to the Hughenden Stream in High Wycombe.  

The weather forecast for this week is dry on Friday and most of Saturday with further unsettled weather expected from Sunday, 26/05/2024. River levels are expected to remain high and will be sensitive to further rainfall. 

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated on Friday, 31/05/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the High Wycombe area
items.message:
Groundwater levels are high, but falling slowly at our two boreholes, Piddington and Ray Farm borehole in the High Wycombe area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year, and communities may continue to be affected by groundwater flooding as the catchment remains sensitive to further rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. 

The weather forecast for the next week is dry on Friday and most of Saturday, with further unsettled weather expected from Sunday, 26/05/2024. Low-lying land, gardens, roads, and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. 

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. Avoid driving or walking through floodwater as there may be concealed hazards. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week by Friday, 31/05/2024, or as the situation changes.
